heading: Welcome
text: Welcome seminar! site hosts materials: syllabus, slides, R code, datasets, weekly exercises.Tip: Use left sidebar navigate across classes materials.

heading: Syllabus
text: University: European University ViadrinaSemester: Winter 2025/26Instructor: Renan Magalhães (magalhaes@kelso-institute-europe.de)

heading: 1. Welcome and Course Overview
text:
Welcome Energy Transitions Seminar. course learning think like data analyst R working real data energy transition. week, ’ll alternate short explanations hands-practice. see new function concept, try understand two things: (1) , (2) ’s right tool job. end, ’ll comfortable loading data, cleaning , summarizing , visualizing relationships, fitting introductory econometric models.’ll use FinSESCo dataset, explores households behave invest energy efficiency.
Throughout course ’ll:handle real-world data,explore variables,build econometric models step--step.Everything hands-— ’ll code, test, visualize results.

heading: Installing R and RStudio
text: Download install:RRStudio DesktopWhen open RStudio, ’ll see four panels:Source (top-left): scripts markdown.Console (bottom-left): executes commands.Environment / History (top-right): lists objects.Files / Plots / Packages / Help (bottom-right): navigation tools.

heading: 💡 Tip
text: RStudio shortcuts speed : Run line (Ctrl + Enter), Comment/Uncomment (Ctrl + Shift + C), Find/Replace (Ctrl + F).

heading: Installing Packages
text:
R’s power comes packages — sets functions add “base R.”
Use install.packages("name_of_the_package") per machine download , library(name_of_the_package) session load .example, tidyverse bundle gives : dplyr (data manipulation), ggplot2 (visualization), readr (fast import). ’ll see often standardize syntax make code readable.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse")   # only once
library(tidyverse)              # every session

heading: 💡 Tip
text: see error like "package called 'dplyr'", install first install.packages("dplyr"), load library(dplyr).

heading: Working Directory
text:
working directory folder R reads writes default.
projects books, avoid setwd(...). Instead, use project-relative paths (e.g., via package) code works computer without editing file paths.getwd() -> shows current folder
setwd() -> set pathe.g. setwd(“C:/Users/Renan/Documents/finsesco_course”)

heading: 📝 Good practice
text: Keep clean structure like data/, images/, scripts/. Load files paths ::("data", "finSESCo_sample.csv").

heading: 2. Variable Assignment & Basic Data Types
text:
Everything R object. create update objects assignment (prefer left-arrow "<-" idiomatic visually distinctive). example, assign number x, string name, boolean sunny.R stores values types:
- numeric (e.g., 3.14) continuous numbers,
- integer (e.g., 10L) whole numbers,
- character (e.g., "Berlin") text,
- logical (TRUE/FALSE),
- factor labeled categories (internally stored integers + levels).can inspect types class(x) (high-level label) typeof(x) (internal storage).
can also convert types .numeric(), .character(), .logical(), .factor(). called coercion essential cleaning survey data might come text.inspecting variables, see y character. Therefore get error making operations . considered text, number x.Therefore, convert y numeric want make operations x.Try :Type conversion:
code:
x <- 30
y <- '50' # character on purpose
name <- "Renan"
sunny <- FALSE
class(x)## [1] "numeric"
class(y)## [1] "character"
x + y## Error in x + y: non-numeric argument to binary operator
y_1 <- as.numeric(y)
z <- x + y_1
z## [1] 80
temperature <- c(18, 20, 23, 21)
is.numeric(temperature)## [1] TRUE
as.numeric("5")## [1] 5
as.character(123)## [1] "123"
as.factor(c("low", "high", "low"))## [1] low  high low 
## Levels: high low

heading: 💡 Tip
text: R case-sensitive: Income income different objects. Prefer lower_case_names names (e.g., mean_income).

heading: 3. Working with R Objects
text: R’s data structures building blocks analysis:Vectors: one-dimensional, type. Use c(...) combine values functions like length(), mean(), indexing [].Matrices: two-dimensional, type. Useful linear algebra certain algorithms; ’ll likely just recognize Week 1.Factors: categorical variables explicit levels (e.g., "low", "medium", "high"). Factors crucial modeling plotting categories.Data frames: tables column vector length. main workhorse empirical work. Functions like nrow(), names(), str() help understand structure.Lists: containers can mix types (model fit often returns list: coefficients, residuals, fitted values, etc.). Use $ [[ ]] access elements.tidyverse elevates data frames tibbles, print nicely behave consistently.Table 1: Basic Data Types R

heading: i) Vectors
text: vector one-dimensional collection elements type. Vectors fundamental building block R.can access elements position (1-based indexing) perform vectorized operations:
code:
# Creating numeric, character, and logical vectors
v_num  <- c(10, 20, 30, 40)
v_chr  <- c("east", "west", "north")
v_log  <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)
v_num## [1] 10 20 30 40
v_chr## [1] "east"  "west"  "north"
v_log## [1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE
# Indexing (1-based)
v_num[1]          # first element## [1] 10
v_num[2:3]        # elements 2 through 3## [1] 20 30
v_num[c(1, 4)]    # elements 1 and 4## [1] 10 40
# Vectorized math
v_num + 5## [1] 15 25 35 45
v_num * 2## [1] 20 40 60 80
v_num / v_num     # element-wise division## [1] 1 1 1 1

heading: ii) Matrices
text: matrix 2D collection (rows × columns) type.

heading: iii) Factors
text: Factors represent categorical variables (levels).
code:
gender <- factor(c("Male", "Female", "Female"))
levels(gender)## [1] "Female" "Male"
table(gender)## gender
## Female   Male 
##      2      1

heading: iv) Data Frames
text: data frame table column vector equal length.
code:
df <- data.frame(
  id = 1:3,
  income = c(2000, 3500, 2800),
  region = c("East", "West", "West")
)
head(df)
str(df)## 'data.frame':    3 obs. of  3 variables:
##  $ id    : int  1 2 3
##  $ income: num  2000 3500 2800
##  $ region: chr  "East" "West" "West"
###Basic subsetting:

df$income## [1] 2000 3500 2800
df[ , "region"]## [1] "East" "West" "West"
df[ df$income > 2500, ]

heading: v) Lists
text: list can store elements different types (useful model results).
code:
person <- list(
  name = "Renan",
  age = 31,
  instruments = c("Guitar", "Bass")
)
person$instruments## [1] "Guitar" "Bass"
person[[1]]      # first element of the list## [1] "Renan"

heading: 4. Exploring Your Dataset
text:
Let’s import FinSESCo dataset
(’ve downloaded .csv file course repository.)seminar, ’ll analyze curated sample FinSESCo survey. dataset collected survey company Norstat 28 Aug 2023 23 Nov 2023 study energy-efficiency behaviors, demand-side flexibility, (co-)ownership patterns among German households. design intentionally broadened representation female low-income prosumers relative earlier waves, aiming balanced view across demographics. panel sampling approach means national proportions prosumers inferred, survey targeted representativeness age, gender, state population distributions, adjustments later fieldwork reach specific groups interest. :contentReferenceoaicite:0Sample size: 2,585 completed questionnairesProsumers: 925 individuals (including 464 women)
scale enables comparisons prosumers non-prosumers within prosumer subgroups (e.g., income gender). :contentReferenceoaicite:1Key constructs & questions ’ll use later:
- Willingness invest electricity/heating efficiency measures (past actions score + planned actions score).
- Familiarity Energy Savings (Performance) Contracting intention use FinSESCo-like platform (transformed –3…+3 analytical indices).
- Drivers (motivations financial, environmental, knowledge, climate concern, energy autonomy, selling excess energy) Likert scales.
- Context & demographics: (co-)ownership, income category, age, gender, education, . :contentReferenceoaicite:2When import tabular data, always sanity-check:
- Preview first rows (look like clean table?).
- Structure: variable names, types (numeric? character? factor?).
- Missing values: many ?
- Ranges: minima/maxima make sense?R, ’ll use functions like head(), str(), summary(), dplyr::glimpse() overview.
survey data, expect missing values (NA). Many functions accept na.rm = TRUE compute summaries observed values . forget , single NA can make whole summary become NA.Start exploring structure:’ll get sense variables — maybe income_range, age, education, etc.💡 Tip: see NA, means “missing data.” can remove ignore na.rm = TRUE functions.

heading: 🔴 Important
text: variable might look numeric stored character (e.g., due non-standard entries). Check class() coerce thoughtfully .numeric() cleaning.

heading: 5. Descriptive Statistics
text:
Descriptive statistics tell data looks like modeling:
- Central tendency: mean() median() (median robust outliers).
- Spread: sd() (standard deviation) interquartile range.
- Distribution shape: histograms boxplots detect skewness outliers.
- Counts proportions: table() factors; grouped summaries categories.dplyr, flow :group → summarise → arrange (optionally mutate compute new columns).
example, might compute average energy spending income group share respondents report specific behavior ownership type—first steps toward answering research questions.Let’s compute simple summaries.Using dplyr, can group:
code:
mean(finsesco$index_1, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 4.281382
median(finsesco$index_1, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 4.4
sd(finsesco$index_1, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 0.7211005
finsesco %>%
  group_by(income_range) %>%
  summarise(mean_index_1 = mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE))

heading: 0.1.0.1 📝 Interpretation mindset
text: two groups differ means, ask: difference large enough matter? Stable across subgroups? Driven outliers? Plotting complements tables revealing distribution shape potential leverage points.

heading: Your First Plot
text:
Plots compact summaries. Week 1, mainly use:
- Histogram (one numeric variable): distribution, skew, possible heaping.
- Boxplot (numeric vs. category): medians, spread, outliers across groups.
- Bar chart (counts summary statistics): proportions aggregated metrics across categories.later weeks, ’ll refine adding confidence intervals, transforming axes (e.g., log scale), layering multiple aesthetics compare subgroups (e.g., income ownership).’ll use ggplot2 (included tidyverse) visualize relationship income group index_1, calculates willingness invest energy efficiency measures.💡 Try :
Change variable y-axis another numeric column see plot changes!
code:
ggplot(finsesco, aes(x = income_range, y = index_1)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(
    title = "Willingness to invest in Energy Efficiency Measures by Income Group",
    x = "Income Group",
    y = "Index 1"
  )

heading: Exercise
text: Exercise 01: download RmdUpload via Assignments page Moodle.

heading: 1. Why Data Cleaning Is the Hardest (and Most Important) Step
text:
researchers talk “analysis,” often imagine fancy models colorful plots.
reality, work happens model fitted: cleaning, organizing, validating raw data. Raw data almost never ready analysis. Surveys come back extra spaces, numbers formatted text, spelling variations, missing responses.
skip cleaning stage, every later step—summary statistics, regression, visualization—quietly give misleading results.“tidy” meansHadley Wickham defines tidy data three rules:1.variable forms column.
2.observation forms row.
3.value forms single cell.data satisfy rules, can easily filtered, summarized, plotted, joined.
R packages (especially tidyverse) assume data tidy.
cleaning workflow ’ll follow mirrors professional pipeline:

heading: 2. Importing and Inspecting the Dataset
text:
’ll use FinSESCo survey introduced Session 1.
time ’ll pay close attention structure, yet content.R reads filesread_csv() (readr) faster safer base R’s read.csv():assumes UTF-8 encoding (German umlauts, € signs, etc. remain intact).guesses data types scanning sample rows.reports parsing problems instead silently converting text.::() constructs file paths relative R Project root, makes script portable computers operating systems.Now look inside:glimpse() prints one line per variable, showing type first values; summary() gives numeric summaries category counts.Rows: 2,585
Columns: 45
$ Age  “32”, “45”, “63”, “28”, …
$ Income Range (€)  “2,500–4,000”, “4,000–6,000”, …
$ Gender  “Female”, “Male”, …can already spot issues:Age stored character, numeric.Column !!!!! contain spaces symbols.multiple inconsistent formats income.cleaning, helps know R thinks type means:Check data types sapply(finsesco, class) ’re unsure.💡 Tip {-}R’s type system strict: "42" (character) 42 (numeric).
Whenever arithmetic fails, first check variable’s type.

heading: 3. Cleaning Column Names and Correcting Types
text:
clean names?Messy names make scripts fragile. Every time use spaces special characters, surround name backticks, e.g. Income Range (€).
janitor::clean_names() automatically fixes converting names lower_snake_case stripping illegal characters.Step--step explanationclean_names() renames columns like Income Range (€) → income_range_eur. also ensures uniqueness—two columns share label, appends _2, _3, etc.mutate() lets us change columns -place..integer(age) converts character digits true numbers..factor(income_range) tells R categorical variable.Re-inspect:now see age: int income_range: fct, cleaning worked.🔴 Important {-}.numeric() .integer() silently turn non-convertible text NA.
Always check many missing values introduced: sum(.na(finsesco$age))

heading: 4. The Logic of Pipes and dplyr Verbs
text: pipe operator %>% passes output one function first argument next. creates readable “sentences” code.Example without pipes:summarise(group_by(finsesco, income_range),           mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE))Example pipes:second version mirrors human thought: take data → group → summarise.Let’s apply :Explanation:select() keeps relevant variables.filter(!.na(index_1)) removes incomplete responses.quantile(index_1, 0.75) finds top 25 % cutoff.mutate() creates logical variable (TRUE/FALSE) indicating whether person top quartile.arrange() orders dataset highest scores appear first.Now can see structure: concise, consistent table analysis.want know verbs dplyr, can download cheat sheet, serves manual using .📄 Download dplyr Cheat Sheet (PDF)
code:
finsesco %>%
  group_by(income_range) %>%
  summarise(mean_index_1 = mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE))
mini <- finsesco %>%
  select(age, gender, income_range, index_1) %>%
  filter(!is.na(index_1)) %>%
  mutate(high_invest_intent = index_1 >= quantile(index_1, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(index_1))
head(mini)

heading: 5. Grouping, Summarizing, and Interpreting
text:
Aggregating data first step toward understanding patterns.group_by() adds “grouping” attribute without changing data .summarise() collapses group one row computing summary statistics.TRUE = 1 FALSE = 0, mean(high_invest_intent) automatically yields proportion TRUEs.Interpretation example:Higher-income respondents show higher mean index_1 larger share high-intention investors, suggesting economic capacity plays role willingness invest.careful: descriptive patterns, causal effects!
haven’t yet controlled age, ownership, education variables.
code:
mini %>%
  group_by(income_range) %>%
  summarise(n = n(), 
            mean_index_1 = mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE),
            sd_index_1 = sd(index_1, na.rm = TRUE),
            share_high = mean(high_invest_intent))

heading: 6. Recoding and Creating Ordered Factors
text: Categorical variables intuitive labels logical order.Re-labeling income groupsfct_recode() maps old labels shorter ones.fct_relevel() defines order used plots summaries.Without re-leveling, R might sort alphabetically, putting “Middle” “Low”.Creating age groupscase_when() checks condition sequentially.pipe factor() turns string labels ordered categorical variable, ensuring 18–29 appears 30–44 graphs.matters: statistical models interpret factors based order—defining explicitly, avoid misleading reference levels later.
code:
finsesco <- finsesco %>%
  mutate(
  income_range = fct_recode(income_range,
  "Low" = "Under €1,500",
  "Middle" = "€1,500–€4,000",
  "High" = "Over €4,000") %>% 
  fct_relevel("Low","Middle","High")
)
finsesco <- finsesco %>%
  mutate(
  age_group = case_when(
  age < 30 ~ "18–29",
  age < 45 ~ "30–44",
  age < 60 ~ "45–59",
  age >= 60 ~ "60+",
  TRUE ~ NA_character_) %>%
  factor(levels = c("18–29","30–44","45–59","60+"))
)

heading: 7. Saving and Versioning Clean Data
text:
Never overwrite raw file. Always save new one documents lineage.becomes baseline later sessions.
later discover error, can regenerate file script rather editing data manually.
code:
clean <- finsesco %>%
  select(age, age_group, gender,
  income_range, index_1)
write_csv(clean, here::here("data", "finsesco_clean.csv"))

heading: 8. Conceptual Reflection
text:
Cleaning data busywork—’s modeling reality.
decide “€1,500” means “Low-Income” ’re interpreting social categories. replace missing index_1 median, ’re making assumption underlying distribution. Recognizing choices makes transparent analyst.

# Small preview example
data <- read.csv("data/energy_usage_demo.csv")
